title: Is ' I go to home' incorrect? If yes, then why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would have written: “I go home.” The “to” leans me in the direction of using “towards.” On the other hand, “I go quickly home” vs. “I go quickly to home” sound the same to my ears. Don’t know why the adverb makes it seem more correct? “I go to run” works, but the “to” is part of the verb “to run.” If an article (such as “a” or “the”) is used, the “to” works well. For example, “I go to the home of my friend.” Or how about: “I go to my home.” “I am going home” works well, while “I am going to home” doesn’t work as well. The “to home” suggests a verb construction. But it is a prepositional-phrase construction.

Many verbs can be followed by a prepositional phrase. With other verbs, the use of a preposition after the verb is redundant. To be certain, consult a dictionary. If the definition of the word ends with a preposition, then do not add another preposition after the verb. Consider the meaning of the verb to determine whether a preposition is redundant or not. In this case, the preposition “to” seems unnecessary after the verb “go”. You should take it out of the phrase.
